Sure, what would you like to discuss? I'd like to understand more about the use cases of Parquet in the wild to decide whether the proposed API in this PR is the right API - is there any Parquet expert you can add also as a reviewer? Eg I suppose people might want to choose to read only a subset of columns, or use filter pushdown. Write might need to be configurable in some way too.

Other notes to modernize this PR:

- The read transform seems to be non-parallel and reads a single file. Is this intentional?
- I would recommend to start right away with a readFiles() version, like in TextIO, so that this can be freely combined with FileIO.match() and FileIO.read(). Is it possible to read chunks of a single Parquet file in parallel? If yes, then might want to use ReadAllFiles and have a BlockBasedSource, but might also just start with a ReadFn (but on top of ReadableFile).
- Likewise I would recommend to implement the write side just as a sink on top of s.apache.org/fileio-write when it is ready (which should be soon enough so I think it makes sense to wait).

Hi, I suppose @ArnaudFnr is a bit busy with the return to school, let me ping him to confirm if he is going to finish this in the next days/weeks, if it is not the case, I will take from the current state and finish his work.
+cc: @chamikaramj  & @katsiapis who @aaltay CC'd on the initial PR as well.
@cclauss if you want to work together on adding flake8 and whitelisting the low false positive errors one at a time I'd be happy to do that with you :)

Parquet is used to serialize and compress proto, thrift and avro files into
queryable column oriented files.  The hard part is that it uses a very api
private internal reader to do a break down and parallelize reading. So the
code to split the input source like with other beam io would have to be
custom

R: @tgroh

@aaltay So on the general case of tuple unpacking in lambdas: that's just gone in Python 3 and its not coming back.

In different places in the code the auto converter has taken different approaches to work around this.
If it's a function we can do multi-line you see things like "xxx_todo_renameme" (or you did before they were renamed but if you look at the commit from running futurize you can see it there) which is then followed by an explicit tuple unpack. In lambdas though that isn't really an option so we do the tuple indexing with compound names.

Some of the lambdas which were too long after auto convert were transformed into def functions and use tuple indexing. I can re-factor these ones to do the explicit tuple unpacking and avoid the indexing if you think it looks nicer.
@peihe

LGTM.  Thanks for the change.

Ugh... I forgot about the API change that included the `InterruptedException`.

A complete parquet implementation would allow pushing down the FilterApi and splitting the workload using the same kind of method that's used in io's like hadoop-file-system not the internal reader as seen here https://github.com/apache/parquet-mr/blob/master/parquet-hadoop/src/main/java/org/apache/parquet/hadoop/ParquetFileReader.java#L141.
I think Beam should read the footers itself to determine how to parallelize the workload.

Thank you for clarifications @holdenk. My preference at least for public facing parts (apis, examples) to re-factor and not use the autoconverted version as-is. For other places I do not have a strong preference, although I think we can improve upon aa_bb_cc kind of naming. 

Some of these work can be follow up PRs as well.

Another question, from the commit history it is not clear what is an automated change, what is a manual change. Is there a way for me to tell which is which?
LGTM, merging

Thanks.

cc: @kennknowles
R: @tgroh

Sure the automated changes are "Futurize stage 1 run", "re-order imports", and "Cleanup whitespace (autopep8 fix" -- the rest are by hand.

I'll dig through the api & examples directory a bit and see what I can do in the scope of this PR and what should maybe be pushed down the road.

Generally I'm trying to do minimal changes over top of the futurize tool (even then it's non-trivial) since we need to do a follow up with stage2 and then fix everything from that (which is going to on the bigger side). And then once more to fix straggler py3 issues. Keeping these PRs like this open for long running time has a non-zero cost since they touch a lot of files in trivial ways merge conflicts will pop up frequently.
